results.title: The Story of Tasmania
results.brief_description: A description of the island of Tasmania, giving something of its history, geography, agriculture and main industries; including discovery and settlement; physical environment; pastoral industries; agricultural, mining, timber and fishing industries; main cities and towns; and Tasmania’s railway system. Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: The Story of sugar
results.brief_description: This classroom film sets out to describe how the white sugar we use every day at mealtimes reaches us in the form we know it best - as white crystals. Although the film deals exclusively with cane sugar, and does not mention the production of sugar from sugar-beet, the films gives a fairly clear picture of the production of sugar in the canefields of northern Australia, and the refining processes carried out in the cities further south.

results.title: The Story of steel
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Industry Series No. 1”.
The story of the manufacture of steel, from the mining of the three raw materials, through the refining process, to the finished product in the rolling mill.

results.title: The Story of Seabiscuit = Pride of Kentucky
results.creator_credit: William Jacobs, Warner Bros Pictures and David Butler
results.brief_description: Irishman Shawn O’Hara (Barry Fitzgerald), a horse trainer with the gift of being able to tell whether a yearling is going to be a winner or not, arrives in Paris, Kentucky, with his niece, Margaret (Shirley Temple) to take up a position at Millford Farms. He is drawn to a horse called Seabiscuit which initially no-one else credits with winning. At the same time a romance slowly blossoms between his niece and jockey Ted Knowles (Lon McCallister). Margaret is reticent at falling in love with a jockey however as she has already lost her brother, also a jockey, when he fell to his death while riding one of Shawn’s horses. The incident caused uncle and niece to flee their native Ireland. Written by John Taintor Foote. Music by David Buttolph. Filmed in Technicolor.

results.title: The Story of Rosy Dock [DVD]
results.brief_description: The story of an elderly woman who ventures into the central Australian desert to set up her home. In her attempt to recreate the beauty of the home she has left, she does not appreciate the beauty that is already there. Written and designed by author and artist Jeannie Baker, and based on her book of the same name, this animated film uses a unique collage of natural materials. It delivers a powerful message about the seemingly harmless practice of importing foreign flora, and how the Earth’s delicately balanced environment is continually being threatened by human interference. Narrated by Michael Craig. Teachers notes are available as a separate loan item with the VHS [306347].

results.title: The Story of Qiu ju = Qiuju da guan si
results.creator_credit: Ma Fung Kwok, Sil-Metropole Organisation, Beijing Film Academy, Youth Film Studio and Chang I-mou
results.brief_description: Set in a small Chinese village, ‘The Story of Qiu Ju’ follows one woman’s crusade to seek justice from the village chief who assaults her husband, Qing Lai, after an argument over Qing’s request to build a shed for drying chilies on prime farming land. Her determination leads her to take on the entire Chinese legal system. A departure from Yimou’s earlier visually sumptuous, period dramas ‘Raise the Red Lantern’ and ‘Ju Dou’, this film adopts a plainer visual style and a satrical tone in observations of contemporary Chinese life and its critique of an overblown and hopelessly ineffective government bureacracy. Based on the novel ‘The Wan Family’s Lawsuit’ by Chen Yuan Bin. Cast includes Gong Li and Lei Que Sheng. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Story of prehistoric man
results.brief_description:
Using artefacts, cave paintings and skeletal remains this film describes the life, appearance, habitat and achievements of prehistoric man including the Old and New Stone Ages.
Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
